lines.text: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Kill the poys and the luggage! 'tis expressly against the law of arms: 'tis as arrant a piece of knavery, mark you now, as can be offer't; in your conscience, now, is it not?

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: 'Tis certain there's not a boy left alive; and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter: besides, they have burned and carried away all that was in the king's tent; wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner's throat. O, 'tis a gallant king!

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain Gower. What call you the town's name where Alexander the Pig was born!

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: Alexander the Great.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Why, I pray you, is not pig great? the pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous, are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon; his father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn. I tell you, captain, if you look in the maps of the 'orld, I warrant you sall find, in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations, look you, is both alike. There is a river in Macedon; and there is also moreover a river at Monmouth: it is called Wye at Monmouth; but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river; but 'tis all one, 'tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both. If you mark Alexander's life well, Harry of Monmouth's life is come after it indifferent well; for there is figures in all things. Alexander, God knows, and you know, in his rages, and his furies, and his wraths, and his cholers, and his moods, and his displeasures, and his indignations, and also being a little intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, look you, kill his best friend, Cleitus.

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: Our king is not like him in that: he never killed any of his friends.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: It is not well done, mark you now take the tales out of my mouth, ere it is made and finished. I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it: as Alexander killed his friend Cleitus, being in his ales and his cups; so also Harry Monmouth, being in his right wits and his good judgments, turned away the fat knight with the great belly-doublet: he was full of jests, and gipes, and knaveries, and mocks; I have forgot his name.

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: Sir John Falstaff.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: That is he: I'll tell you there is good men porn at Monmouth.

lines.speaker: gower
lines.text: Here comes his majesty. Alarum. Enter KING HENRY, and forces; WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, EXETER, and others

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: I was not angry since I came to France Until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald; Ride thou unto the horsemen on yon hill: If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field; they do offend our sight: If they'll do neither, we will come to them, And make them skirr away, as swift as stones Enforced from the old Assyrian slings: Besides, we'll cut the throats of those we have, And not a man of them that we shall take Shall taste our mercy. Go and tell them so.
Enter MONTJOY

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: How now! what means this, herald? know'st thou not That I have  fined these bones of mine for ransom? Comest thou again for ransom?

lines.speaker: montjoy
lines.text: No, great king: I come to thee for charitable licence, That we may wander o'er this bloody field To look our dead, and then to bury them; To sort our nobles from our common men. For many of our princes--woe the while!-- Lie drown'd and soak'd in mercenary blood; So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs In blood of princes; and their wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore and with wild rage Yerk out their armed heels at their dead masters, Killing them twice. O, give us leave, great king, To view the field in safety and dispose Of their dead bodies!

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: I tell thee truly, herald, I know not if the day be ours or no; For yet a many of your horsemen peer And gallop o'er the field.

lines.speaker: montjoy
lines.text: The day is yours.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it! What is this castle call'd that stands hard by?

lines.speaker: montjoy
lines.text: They call it Agincourt.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Then call we this the field of Agincourt, Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Your grandfather of famous memory, an't please your majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in France.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: They did, Fluellen.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Your majesty says very true: if your majesties is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps; which, your majesty know, to this hour is an honourable badge of the service; and I do believe your majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy's day.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: I wear it for a memorable honour; For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: All the water in Wye cannot wash your majesty's Welsh plood out of your pody, I can tell you that: God pless it and preserve it, as long as it pleases his grace, and his majesty too!

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Thanks, good my countryman.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: By Jeshu, I am your majesty's countryman, I care not who know it; I will confess it to all the 'orld: I need not to be ashamed of your majesty, praised be God, so long as your majesty is an honest man.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: God keep me so! Our heralds go with him: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead On both our parts. Call yonder fellow hither.
Points to WILLIAMS. Exeunt Heralds with Montjoy

lines.speaker: exeter
lines.text: Soldier, you must come to the king.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Soldier, why wearest thou that glove in thy cap?

lines.speaker: williams
lines.text: An't please your majesty, 'tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: An Englishman?

lines.speaker: williams
lines.text: An't please your majesty, a rascal that swaggered with me last night; who, if alive and ever dare to challenge this glove, I have sworn to take him a box o' th' ear: or if I can see my glove in his cap, which he swore, as he was a soldier, he would wear if alive, I will strike it out soundly.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: What think you, Captain Fluellen? is it fit this soldier keep his oath?

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: He is a craven and a villain else, an't please your majesty, in my conscience.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort, quite from the answer of his degree.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is, as Lucifer and Belzebub himself, it is necessary, look your grace, that he keep his vow and his oath: if he be perjured, see you now, his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jacksauce, as ever his black shoe trod upon God's ground and his earth, in my conscience, la!

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meetest the fellow.

lines.speaker: williams
lines.text: So I will, my liege, as I live.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Who servest thou under?

lines.speaker: williams
lines.text: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Call him hither to me, soldier.

lines.speaker: williams
lines.text: I will, my liege.
Exit

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Here, Fluellen; wear thou this favour for me and stick it in thy cap: when Alencon and myself were down together, I plucked this glove from his helm: if any man challenge this, he is a friend to Alencon, and an enemy to our person; if thou encounter any such, apprehend him, an thou dost me love.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: Your grace doo's me as great honours as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects: I would fain see the man, that has but two legs, that shall find himself aggrieved at this glove; that is all; but I would fain see it once, an please God of his grace that I might see.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Knowest thou Gower?

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: He is my dear friend, an please you.

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.

lines.speaker: fluellen
lines.text: I will fetch him.
Exit

lines.speaker: king henry the fifth
lines.text: My Lord of Warwick, and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels: The glove which I have given him for a favour May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear; It is the soldier's; I by bargain should Wear it myself. Follow, good cousin Warwick: If that the soldier strike him, as I judge By his blunt bearing he will keep his word, Some sudden mischief may arise of it; For I do know Fluellen valiant And, touched with choler, hot as gunpowder, And quickly will return an injury: Follow and see there be no harm between them. Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.
Exeunt
